title: Asia stocks up slightly in cautious trade as focus shifts to U.S. payrolls
text: Asian stocks edged higher on Friday, thanks to gains on Wall Street, but the mood was cautious before a key U.S. job report  that could help determine whether the Federal Reserve cuts interest rates further.

title: Will Get a Quarter Point Cut in October From Fed, Says FTN Financial’s Low
text: Oct.03 -- Chris Low, chief economist at FTN Financial, discusses the U.S.

title: Asian markets are muted, and economy worries aren't going away
text: Asian markets were somewhat tepid Friday as worries persist over the global economy.

title: Oil edges higher but on track for big weekly loss
text: Oil futures edged higher on Friday but were on track for a large weekly loss on fears that slower global economic growth will hurt fuel demand, while Saudi Arabia said it has fully restored oil output after recent attacks.

title: Asia stocks edge higher but markets on tenterhooks ahead of U.S. payrolls
text: Asian stocks edged higher on Friday, thanks to gains on Wall Street, but the mood was cautious before a key U.S. job report  that could help determine whether the Federal Reserve cuts interest rates further.

title: Trade wars with the EU, China could be 'self-defeating' for the economy and Trump's presidency, Jim
text: "Mr. President: It's time to get a deal done, something not unilateral, just to show that we still have a functioning government when it comes to trade," "Mad Money's" Jim Cramer says.

title: Jim Cramer explains how to judge this earnings season: 'Not as bad as feared'
text: If stocks drop after the September nonfarm payroll report is released, here are some stocks investors can play, says Jim Cramer.

title: Another Fed Rate Cut Is Expected After Weak Economic Data
text: Key officials said they were open minded about the need for further cuts. Then a flurry of bad economic data rolled in.

title: The man who called the meltdown now sees this in the charts
text: Cornerstone Macro's Carter Worth on the next key levels to watch. With CNBC's Melissa Lee and the Fast Money traders, Karen Finerman, Brian Kelly and Tim Seymour.

title: Bank of America's Mark Cabana on make or break moment for Fed
text: Bank of America's Mark Cabana discusses the Fed, the market and tomorrow's jobs report.

title: Roller-coaster Thursday: Dow closes with markets back to session highs
text: Portfolio manager of The Villere Balanced Fund George Young talks about markets, semiconductor chip stocks, the 5G network race and more.

title: IndexIQ Launches Liquid Alternative ETF Model With Nasdaq Dorsey Wright
text: Advisors looking for lower-cost, innovative hedge fund strategies in a unique investment model can now do so thanks to a new partnership between IndexIQ and Nasdaq Dorsey Wright. The companies have come together to offer the IQ Alternative Allocation Model, the first liquid alternative model on Nasdaq Dorsey Wright’s platform.

title: M&A Activity to Be Constrained for the Next Year, Kirkland & Ellis' Wolf Says
text: Daniel Wolf, Kirkland & Ellis M&A partner, discusses the outlook for M&A activity with Bloomberg's Ed Hammond on "Bloomberg Markets: The Close.

title: EU to put retaliatory tariffs on US
text: University of Maryland Economist Peter Morici discusses his concerns over the E.U.

title: Markets rebound in major comeback -- five experts weigh in
text: Stocks showed a major recovery on Thursday, snapping a two-day losing streak for the S&P 500, Dow and Nasdaq. Five experts weigh in on what investors should watch for as the markets fluctuate.

title: No reason to believe yields for 10-year Treasury will go up: Jim Bianco
text: Stephanie Link from Nuveen and Jim Bianco from Bianco Research join CNBC's "Closing Bell" to discuss the day's market action as stocks close at session highs.

title: Stock Market Today: Stocks Bounce Ahead of Jobs Report
text: Here's what happened in the stock market today, as equities posted a strong bounce after an early morning flush.

title: Dow Jones Today: A Rebound With an Asterisk
text: The ISM services report is the latest in a recent spate of glum economic data and the tests continue tomorrow with the publication of the September jobs report from the Labor Department. With that in mind, today's market upside may be a simple case of a rebound after a couple of bad days or expectations that the Federal Reserve will lower interest rates again later this month.

title: Stocks climb as soft data fuels rate cut hopes
text: Wall Street climbed on Thursday after data showing services-sector activity at a three-year low fueled expectations the Federal Reserve would cut interest rates in an effort to thwart a wider economic downturn.

title: State Street Report: $15B Goes Into Fixed Income ETFs
text: Worries of global growth as a result of the U.S.-China trade war saw investors opt for more safety via bonds.

title: Daily Repo Actions Starting to Smooth Out Markets, Goldman's Hammack Says
text: Beth Hammack, Goldman Sachs global treasurer, discusses the long-term effects of the Federal Reserve's daily repo operations with Bloomberg's Scarlet Fu, Sonali Basak and Caroline Hyde on "Bloomberg Markets: The Close.

title: Drop in Oil Prices Causing Pain for High-Yield Energy Bonds
text: Bloomberg's Lisa Abramowicz takes a look at how the drop in oil prices is impacting high-yield energy bonds.

title: Three before you leave — What to watch for in the market Friday (Oct 04)
text: We'll get the government's latest jobs report, Sec. Pompeo's subpoena deadline and speeches from a host of Federal Reserve officials.

title: US Indexes Close Higher Thursday (Oct 03)
text: The Dow Jones Industrial Average closed at 26,201.04 on Thursday with a gain of 122.42 points or 0.47%.

title: Fed Has Lost Control of Yield Curve and Needs to Cut Rates, Economist Schomer Says
text: Markus Schomer, Pinebridge Investments chief economist, explains why the Federal Reserve needs to cut interest rates.

title: We have suffered a slowdown, the Fed has to move: Wharton's Siegel
text: CNBC's "Closing Bell" team breaks down how markets with Stephanie Link of Nuveen; Jeremy Siegel, finance professor at Wharton; and Richard Bernstein of Richard Bernstein Advisors.

title: Have a little more pain left in October: Stock Trader's Almanac's Hirsch
text: Jeff Hirsch of the Stock Trader's Almanac discusses what he calls, "October-phobia," alongside Steve Grasso, a "Fast Money" trader, with the "Power Lunch" team.

title: Bearish 'death cross' appears in Russell 2000 chart, first since just before December flash selloff
text: A bearish "death cross" pattern is appearing in the Russell 2000's RUT, +0.39% chart Thursday, for the first time in about 11 months.

title: Wall Street Rebounds on Thursday
text: U.S. stocks were in the green on Thursday as investors are anticipating a rate cut from the Federal Reserve later this month.

title: Chinese companies listing on NYSE should follow the same rules: Larry Lindsey
text: Larry Lindsey, CEO of the Lindsey Group and former director of the National Economic Council under President George W. Bush, joins "The Exchange" to discuss the trade war, The Federal Reserve's decisions and more.

title: Trade war must be resolved for industrials sector to improve, JP Morgan analyst says
text: Ann Duignan, managing director at J.P. Morgan, joins "The Exchange" to discuss challenges facing the industrials sector.

title: Retail analyst: Go with high-end, low-end or specialties that excel
text: CNBC's "Power Lunch" team breaks down what the retail sector is signaling with Oliver Chen, senior retail analyst and managing director at Cowen.

title: All Fed can do now is provide 'confidence band-aid': BNY Mellon director
text: Liz Young, BNY Mellon Director of Market Strategy, joins "Fast Money: Halftime Report" to discuss the market as stocks erase early losses.

title: Not clear if this is soft patch or something worse: Portfolio manager
text: CNBC's "Power Lunch" team discusses the possibility of a recession with Michael Farr, a CNBC contributor; Bill Stone of Avalon Investment; and Margaret Vitrano of ClearBridge Investments Large Cap Growth Fund.

title: Non-Transparent ETFs: The Potential Impacts on the Market
text: The non-transparent ETF structure continues to gain traction among active ETF managers who value the confidential nature of these investments. Unlike typical ETFs, non-transparent ETF managers don’t have to disclose their fund’s investments every day.

title: Investors Ready for a Slowdown, Not a Recession: State Street
text: Michael Metcalfe, global head of macro strategy at State Street Global Markets, discusses investor sentiment and the outlook for a global recession on "Bloomberg Markets: European Close.

title: U.S. recession risks up as services growth hits three-year low
text: U.S. services sector activity slowed to a three-year low in September amid rising concerns about tariffs, suggesting that trade tensions were spilling over to the broader economy.

title: Friday's jobs report should show hiring is slowing, but not that a recession is near
text: Hiring is slowing but the September employment report should be just solid enough—and not reflect anything near the onset of a recession.

title: Historically, October most volatile market month: WFC's McMillion
text: Dan Suzuki, Richard Bernstein Advisors portfolio strategist, and Tracie McMillion, Wells Fargo Investment Institute head of global asset allocation strategy, join 'Squawk Alley' to discuss why markets are reversing on losses and how the economic slowdown weighs into it.

title: Retailers expect a strong holiday shopping season, even as the trade war looms
text: Retailers expect consumers to deliver another strong holiday shopping season, even as the trade war hangs over the economy.

title: Jobs Report: Bad News For U.S. Economy Won't Be Good News For Dow Jones
text: If a weak jobs report reinforces fears that the U.S. economy is headed for a recession, don't expect the Dow Jones to rally on Fed rate-cut prospects.

title: U.S. to See Slower Growth But Not a Recession, Mariposa CEO Franklin Says
text: Oct.03 -- Martin Franklin, Jarden co-founder and Mariposa Capital chief executive officer, comments on the outlook for the U.S.

title: Market gyrates as traders digest realities of slower growth
text: Traders seem to have been positioned bearish, convinced weak manufacturing data would bleed into the consumer. But the significant market drop this week — 1,000 points in the Dow Industrials — may have gone a bit too far.

title: Trump administration slaps 25% tariffs in EU goods
text: Yahoo Finance's Jessica Smith reports on the Trump administration  imposing tariffs on airplanes, food, liquor, and other goods from Europe.

title: U.S. duties on French wine are bad news for all, exporters say
text: The U.S. decision to impose tariffs on French wines will penalize American consumers who will see a sharp rise in prices while severely hurting French producers on their largest export market, exporters said on Thursday.

title: What happens if the Fed cuts rates to zero -- or goes negative?
text: Say what you will about President Trump's unusually loud critiques of Jerome Powell. But Trump is not wrong that interest rates in the United States, even after two recent cuts, are higher than much of the rest of the developed world.

title: Russell CEO Says 'We Should All Be More Nervous' in Active Management
text: Michelle Seitz, chief executive officer at Russell Investments, discusses the future of active management and her expectations for changes within the industry.

title: What Went Wrong With WeWork?
text: Oct.03 -- CEO Adam Neumann stepped down after plans for an IPO fizzled out.

title: The IPO Market Lacks Discipline, Mariposa CEO Franklin Says
text: Martin Franklin, Jarden co-founder and Mariposa Capital chief executive officer, comments on the current state of the IPO market during an interview with Bloomberg's Vonnie Quinn, Ed Hammond and Guy Johnson on "Bloomberg Markets.

title: Goldman's Gnodde on Markets, Wealth Management, Brexit, China
text: Oct.03 -- Richard Gnodde, chief executive officer at Goldman Sachs International, discusses a convergence of issues he sees impacting markets, prioritizing wealth management in Europe, the impact of Brexit uncertainty, and China's financial markets.
